node.title: Scrambling but Undaunted, the Met Opera Sings Through Omicron
node.description: The variant has upended Broadway, ballet and concerts. But the Met has yet to miss a performance, thanks to strict rules, fill-in artists and luck.

node.title: Why virtual and augmented reality will come to life in 2022
node.description: Sony, Panasonic, HTC and other consumer electronics companies are releasing new VR and metaverse products at CES.

node.title: Post office delivers a letter with only a "life story" as an address
node.description: Postal workers were able to work out who the letter was meant for from facts about the recipient written on the envelope.

node.title: Map helps man reunite with family decades after "bad people" abducted him
node.description: Abducted in 1989, Li Jingwei was able to find his mother decades later after a meticulous drawing of his village helped police locate his family.

node.title: Record number of Florida manatees died in 2021
node.description: Preliminary data shows there were more than 1,100 reported manatee deaths in Florida last year — nearly double the five-year average.

node.title: Ahmaud Arbery's family rejected plea deal for hate crime charges
node.description: Travis McMichael, his father Gregory McMichael and William "Roddie" Bryan were convicted in state murder charges in November.​

node.title: Job growth slipped to 199,000 in December, short of forecasts
node.description: Economists had expected about 400,000 hires. The jobless rate fell to 3.9%, the lowest since the start of the pandemic.

node.title: Alleged Capitol rioter accused of DWI in fatal wrong-way crash
node.description: Troopers say Emily Hernandez' car hit another on I-44 in the St. Louis area, killing a passenger in the other car. She's charged with five misdemeanors stemming from the January 6 assault.

node.title: Are Omicron's symptoms different? New studies offer clues
node.description: Some distinctive COVID-19 symptoms, like loss of taste and smell, now appear to be less common.

node.title: Watch Live: Men convicted of Ahmaud Arbery's murder are sentenced
node.description: A jury found the 3 men guilty in November for the shooting death of Ahmaud Arbery.

node.title: Washington Football Team Plans Name Unveil Even as Bad News Mounts
node.description: Two days after fans at the team’s stadium fell when a railing collapsed, the team announced a Feb. 2 — Groundhog Day — launch date for its long-awaited rebranding.

node.title: ‘The N.F.L. Is Another No-Good Entity’
node.description: Eric Dickerson talks about why some former players hate the N.F.L., his assumption that he has C.T.E., and why his single-season rushing record isn’t his most unbreakable.

node.title: Jonelle Matthews' suspected killer admits he lied to investigators
node.description: Steven Pankey, charged with kidnapping and killing the 12-year-old girl, told a Colorado jury "one lie leads to another"

node.title: Biden denounces Trump's "web of lies" while Congress marks one year since January 6 attack
node.description: The president warned that democracy is at risk, asking, "Are we going to be a nation that lives not by the light of the truth but in the shadow of lies?"

node.title: Kazakhstan leader rejects talks, tells forces to "shoot to kill"
node.description: Unprecedented protests in the former Soviet Republic challenged its authoritarian regime. Now the leader is thanking Russia for help, and vowing instigators will be "destroyed."

node.title: Here's who could get a bigger — or smaller — tax refund
node.description: Some taxpayers may be surprised when the expanded Child Tax Credit shrinks their refund, tax experts say.

node.title: Fire that destroyed Planned Parenthood building was set: officials
node.description: The fire was the second time the clinic was targeted last year. Someone fired a shotgun at the clinic's doors in January, shattering glass and leaving holes in the reception area.

node.title: Japan reimposing restrictions as U.S. troops blamed for COVID surge
node.description: The American military command has resisted calls from Japanese officials to lock down bases, but U.S. troops now must follow the same rules as civilians upon entering the country.

node.title: WWII soldier's letter to mom delivered 76 years after it was sent
node.description: The letter — written on December 6, 1945 — would sit unopened before being found in a USPS distribution facility in Pittsburgh.

node.title: Dozens of Hong Kong officials are sent into quarantine after a birthday party.
node.description: Those being sent to shipping-container-like dormitories include the city’s police chief and at least 20 lawmakers.

node.title: Supreme Court to consider Biden's vaccine requirements
node.description: The disputes over the vaccine rules for health care workers and businesses with at least 100 employees arrived at the Supreme Court through emergency requests.

node.title: Georgia secretary of state on how 2020 election changed his life
node.description: On "The Takeout" podcast this week, Major Garrett looks back at the January 6 Capitol attack and the threats posed by those who denied the election results.

node.title: Twenty Yellowstone wolves killed by hunters after roaming from park
node.description: Park officials call the deaths "a significant setback for the species' long-term viability and for wolf research." One pack is now considered "eliminated."

node.title: 10 murder victims' bodies dumped in front of Mexico governor's office
node.description: Zacatecas state, torn by a battle between two powerful cartels, has one of the highest homicide rates in Mexico.

node.title: F.D.R.’s Court-Packing Plan Had Two Parts. We Need to Bring Back the Second.
node.description: Roosevelt warned about courts becoming a “third house of the national legislature.” History may be on the verge of repeating itself.

node.title: Our Democracy Isn’t Just Going to Fix Itself
node.description: It needs your help.

node.title: ‘Trump’s People Don’t Act Like That’: How Republican Voters See Jan. 6
node.description: The Republicans aren’t apologists for Jan. 6 — some chastised President Trump and don’t want him to run again. They just want the country to move on.

node.title: ‘It’s Going to Be the White House Next’: Nine Democrats Grapple with Jan. 6
node.description: The lack of consequences for Republican leaders over Jan. 6 has Democrats worried for the future.  But some also expressed empathy for the rioters.

node.title: They Had Reasons for Leaving the City. So Why Are Their Friends Mad?
node.description: When Covid hit, some New Yorkers abandoned the city for good. They left some angry friends.

node.title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
node.description: Selections from the current Weekend section, including a preview of “Euphoria” and other TV shows coming this winter.
